snippet: To the Editor:    In a June 2 news article, ''Blacks Would Feel Extra Impact From Cuts Proposed by President,'' David E. Rosenbaum reports that the median income of black families fell from 63 percent of that of white families in 1969 to 57 percen...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a June 2 news article, ''Blacks Would Feel Extra Impact From Cuts Proposed by President,'' David E. Rosenbaum reports that the median income of black families fell from 63 percent of that of white families in 1969 to 57 percent for the most recent census tabulations. e does not describe a fundamental reason for the deterioration - the substantially faster growth of female-headed families among blacks than among whites. In fact, if the proportion of two-adult families for each race had been the same in 1978 as in 1970, the black/white income gap would have narrowed by 5 percentage points in that period.

headline.main: Letters; BEHIND A STATISTIC ON BLACKS' INCOME

snippet: IF our conventional wisdom is right    and the middle class really is the   social glue that holds society together, then America is in the process of becoming unglued.   A middle-class household is frequently defined as one with an income between...
lead_paragraph: IF our conventional wisdom is right and the middle class really is the social glue that holds society together, then America is in the process of becoming unglued. A middle-class household is frequently defined as one with an income between 75 percent and 125 percent of the median household income. If so, then the middle class - which falls into an income range of $15,100 to $25,200 in 1982 - has declined from 28.2 percent of the population in 1967 to 23.7 percent now. Even when slightly different definitions of income factors constituting a middle class are applied to the statistics, the trend is not reversed. The American middle class is disappearing.

headline.main: THE DISAPPEARANCE OF THE MIDDLE CLASS

abstract: US Census Bur statistical study finds that while women have made substantial gains in life expectancy, educ and employment since turn of century, income gap between men and women continues to widen; finds employment for women has doubled since '50, while number of working men increased by only 25%; says avg annual income for full time working men during same period rose more rapidly than for women workers; '74 median income for women was $6,957; figure is 57% of avg '74 male income; '70 figures show median income for women was $5,440, compared with $9,184 for men (S)

headline.main: Male Workers' Pay Continues to Widen Gap Over Women
The Civil Service.

snippet: The Census Bureau today issued a report on household income that confirms neither President Reagan's view of his tax cut nor the views of his Democratic critics.    The report suggests that there has been a small increase in the concentration of i...
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau today issued a report on household income that confirms neither President Reagan's view of his tax cut nor the views of his Democratic critics. The report suggests that there has been a small increase in the concentration of income among high-income households but nothing like the radical shift in that direction suggested by Mr. Reagan's critics. The Administration has generally denied that there has been any increase in the concentration of income among households of the affluent. Mr. Reagan said the tax cut had been more beneficial to ''people at the lower end of the earning scale'' than to anyone else. The Census Bureau report said that in 1982, a recession year, average household income rose after taxes to $18,910, a climb of 1.7 percent from 1981 after adjustment to account for inflation.

headline.main: CENSUS DATA SHOW RESULT OF TAX CUT

snippet: Women are producing ever more food, but not reaping enough gains....
lead_paragraph: Women are producing ever more food, but not reaping enough gains.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Olivier De Schutter notes farming across the developing world is increasingly overseen by women; identifies ways in which governments and organizations can empower such women by removing obstacles that frustrate their rise out of poverty and hunger.

headline.main: The Feminization of Farming
headline.print_headline: The Feminization of Farming

snippet: DWYER--Dr. Daisy Hilse, on February 26th, at home after a long illness. She taught at Columbia University after receiving her doctorate from Yale, and authored "images and Self-Images: Male and Female in Morocco," and "A Home Divided: Women and In...
lead_paragraph: DWYER--Dr. Daisy Hilse, on February 26th, at home after a long illness. She taught at Columbia University after receiving her doctorate from Yale, and authored "images and Self-Images: Male and Female in Morocco," and "A Home Divided: Women and Income in the Third World," with Judith Bruce. She later obtained a law degree from Columbia, and was Of Counsel for many years with Dewey-Ballantine. She is survived by her husband, son, and brother.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, DAISY H.
Correction

snippet: The bike-share program is making efforts to serve all New Yorkers, but officials say the system might not reach all boroughs unless the city helps pay for it....
lead_paragraph: The bike-share program is making efforts to serve all New Yorkers, but officials say the system might not reach all boroughs unless the city helps pay for it.
abstract: Some New York City leaders are calling for Citi Bike program to expand into low-income neighborhoods in Bronx and Staten Island: Citi Bike officials say expansion will require additional funding, option Mayor Bill de Blasio is considering.

headline.main: Citi Bike Under Pressure to Expand to Low-Income Neighborhoods
headline.print_headline: Citi Bike Pressed to Expand to Low-Income Areas

snippet: Female donors are putting more money into campaigns than they ever have, at every elective level and in both major parties....
lead_paragraph: Female donors are putting more money into campaigns than they ever have, at every elective level and in both major parties.
abstract: Women are making record level of donations to 2016 political campaigns, driven by their growing prominence in workplace and expansion of networks created to increase their political influence; women have contributed 43 percent of all reported donations to federal candidates in 2016, at all levels of giving, trend that could significantly influence politics on national level.

headline.main: Women’s Rising Influence in Politics, Tinted Green
headline.print_headline: Women Build Political Clout as Big Donors

snippet: Women are more likely than men to be in a minimum-wage job, and they’re also more likely to be raising a family on their own....
lead_paragraph: Women are more likely than men to be in a minimum-wage job, and they’re also more likely to be raising a family on their own.
abstract: The Upshot; while women in work force have made more progress than men over past three decades when it comes to wages, they are still more likely to be in minimum-wage job and raising a family on their own; trend reveals that women at lowest income levels feel burden of inequality more deeply than men.

headline.main: Among the Poor, Women Feel Inequality More Deeply
headline.print_headline: Among the Poor, Women Feel Inequality More Deeply

snippet: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor of New York City, spent Monday reaching out....
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor of New York City, spent Monday reaching out.
abstract: New York City Council Speaker Christine C Quinn, only woman in crowded field of Democratic candidates for New York City mayor, is making a concerted effort to reach out to female voters as primary election nears; she is attending events that highlight her interest in women's issues and her support from prominent women.

headline.main: Lone Woman in Mayoral Race Steps Up Appeal to Female Voters
headline.print_headline: Lone Woman in Mayoral Race Steps Up Appeal to Female Voters

snippet: Mr. Trump’s call for six weeks of mandatory paid maternity leave and expanded tax credits for child care is another attempt to court elusive support from women....
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump’s call for six weeks of mandatory paid maternity leave and expanded tax credits for child care is another attempt to court elusive support from women.
abstract: Donald Trump reveals plan aimed at helping working parents in attempt to court female voters, who have been alienated throughout his campaign; menu of proposals includes six weeks of mandatory paid maternity leave and expanded tax credits for child care; social conservatives praise plan, but some child care advocacy groups express doubt it would be helpful.

headline.main: Donald Trump Unveils Plan for Families in Bid for Women’s Votes
headline.print_headline: Trump Unveils Plan to Expand Aid to Parents

snippet: Those who stay at home report more sadness, anger and depression....
lead_paragraph: Those who stay at home report more sadness, anger and depression.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Stephanie Coontz notes that women who choose not to work and stay at home report more sadness, anger and depression than those who choose to work outside the home; contends country should start implementing social policies and working conditions that allow families to take full advantage of benefits of women's employment.

headline.seo: The Triumph of the Working Mother
headline.main: The Triumph of the Working Mother
headline.print_headline: The Triumph of the Working Mother

snippet: What workers really need are higher wages....
lead_paragraph: What workers really need are higher wages.
abstract: Op-Ed article by policy expert Lawrence Mishel criticizes plans by both political parties to address long-term wage stagnation through tax cuts; suggests more effective means, including postponing interest rate hikes, avoiding trade deals and raising minimum wage and cracking down on wage theft.

headline.main: Even Better Than a Tax Cut
headline.print_headline: Even Better Than a Tax Cut
